title: 112_s1502
content:
The "Clean Rivers Act of 2011" defines key terms such as "appropriate congressional committees," "gathering lines," "hazardous liquid pipeline facility," and "Indian tribe." SEC. 3. REVIEW OF PIPELINE RIVER CROSSINGS. The Administrator of the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration must review regulations for pipelines crossing inland bodies of water within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The review includes data on river geomorphology, depth of cover requirements, inspection mandates during extraordinary events, and Integrity Management Plans evaluations. The Administrator of the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration must review regulations for pipelines crossing inland bodies of water within 180 days of the Act's enactment. This includes evaluations of flooding probability and consequences at river crossings, requirements for installing crossings with horizontal directional drilling, and issuance of emergency orders for unsafe conditions. Consultation with relevant federal, regional, state, Tribal, and local entities is required. A report must be submitted within 30 days of completing the review. The Administrator must submit a report to congressional committees within 30 days after reviewing regulations for pipelines crossing inland bodies of water. Within one year of the report, regulations must be prescribed to incorporate review findings and recommendations. SEC. 4. INCREASED TRANSPARENCY. The Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration will establish a database of pipeline water crossings in the US, including details like operator, design classification, depth of cover, installation date, inspection dates, anomalies, and operational status during high flows. Additionally, they will provide national statistics on a publicly available website. The Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration will publish national and state statistics on pipeline safety on their website, including percentages of pipeline crossings and miles inspected by in-line inspection, High Consequence Areas, compliance rates, types of pipeline crossings, and more. The Administrator will post information on hazardous liquid pipeline response plans, including status of plan reviews, plan requirements, and summaries of approved plans excluding certain sensitive information. The Administrator will require pipeline operators to consult with local first responders and emergency services operators in constructing and updating oil spill response plans. Approved plans must be filed with all listed local responders and services. SEC. 5. LEAK DETECTION PERFORMANCE STANDARDS.

Within one year of this Act's enactment, the Administrator of the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration will assess the need for leak detection system standards for hazardous liquid pipeline operators, focusing on leak size detection capabilities and alarm response times.

SEC. 6. EMERGENCY FLOW RESTRICTING DEVICES.

Within one year of this Act's enactment, the Administrator will review regulations concerning the use of emergency flow restricting devices by operators of hazardous liquid pipeline facilities.

SEC. 7. ONSHORE GATHERING LINES. SEC. 7. ONSHORE GATHERING LINES. The Administrator will review unregulated onshore gas and hazardous liquid gathering lines, assess existing laws and regulations for pipeline safety, and consider applying regulations to these lines. Recommendations will be made on modifying or revoking exemptions based on a risk-based assessment. SEC. 8. LOCAL AUTHORITY INVOLVEMENT. The National Contingency Plan will be revised to involve local authorities more in the response management structure for oil and hazardous substances. The On-Scene Coordinator's role will remain unchanged. 

SEC. 9. TRIBAL CONSULTATION. The Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration will establish a protocol for consulting with Indian tribes within a year of this Act's enactment. Operators of pipelines on tribal land must submit oil spill response plans to the Administration.
